title: Career Paths in Research - Structural Change
segmentation: Good morning ladies and gentlemen, let me welcome you to this morning session.
First session of today, which is on career paths and structural change.
My name is Alexandra Bitter Sicola and I am from Slovakia.
I come from my table University in Banska Bistrita and I was one or I still M1 of the gendera partners.
My background is in social anthropology at the moment.
I am also the vice Rector for research at my University and now I really can see what it means to be in a decision-making position.

I regretted it several times already that I took it that somehow I took it, mainly because I am lecturing about the need of having more women in decision making positions, and when I was asked to take this position first, I said no way.
And then I started to think how I should do something myself.
So here I am.
So today we have 4 nice speakers.
But before we start I.
Would just like to tell you a few more few words of an introduction to the topic.
I don't need to stress you the importance of structure change well, especially in the country like Slovakia, where I'm from we really need something also.
It has to be some measures and practices which have to be introduced.
Maybe more in than in other countries.
Structure change really should create conditions for appealing attractive and sustainable careers for both women and men.
I don't know whether you are familiar with this document, which I put here because I found it quite interesting.
Recommendations to the Member States from the Commission it was working group.

And the workshop with the outcomes which are on the website, you can Google them under this titles last year and it was really focused mainly the workshop and also the outcomes on structure change so.
I was inspired a bit and just summarized a few things out of this reportes and out of my experience.
So first, why to and how to initiate structure change what we need.
We need, of course, raising awareness and education from the early childhood.
Gender sensitive.
We need to setting some institutional standards and guidelines.
We need to involve policymakers.
I find it very important.
It's very difficult to do.
The change just from the bottom up you need also some pressure from the top down direction.
Of course, institutional leaders as well.
We need support from and raise awareness among gatekeepers and funding organisations.
And we need some funding to do that also then how to sustain the structure change and implement?
Well, we need to set in place some instruments for implementation.
We need to think of cultural change and management change in our organisations.
Transparency of recruitment procedures.
Changing practices for retaining women in research and also maybe to change some mobility patterns and peer review.
And then if we have that, we still need to monitor all these processes as it was already set today, we can't.
It's not enough to have good legislation in most of our new Member States.
Countries.
We had to implement all EU directives, also those which are related to gender equality.
So we have nice legislation, but whether it works in practice, that's another matter.
So we need monitoring and benchmarking and audits.
So in the end I can say at the end of my short introduction we need a holistic approach towards gender equality.
On the one hand, adoption of legal instruments, but also introducing all kinds of innovative practices with which touch multi layer dimensions.
And the incentives for bringing forward gender equality.
I'm not going to talk more because we have 4 speakers and not much time, so that's enough from me.
Thank you very much.
